Key Laboratory of Advanced Carbon-Based Functional Materials Fujian Key Laboratory of Electrochemical Energy Storage Materials State Key Laboratory of Photocatalysis on Energy and Environment College of Chemistry Fuzhou University Fuzhou 350108 China Tuning metal-support interactions in catalysts represents a promising strategy for optimizing the catalytic activity of CO2 hydrogenation. Here, CuZnZr ternary catalysts with varied interfacial structures were fabricated by altering the metal loading sequence to elucidate the interactions between different counterparts. Compared to reference catalysts with different interfaces (Cu-ZnZr, Zn-CuZr and Zr-CuZn), CuZnZr synthesized via the coprecipitation method (CZZ) displays the highest catalytic performance, achieving a CO2 conversion rate of 13.3 %, methanol selectivity of 71.3 %, and a STY of 12.2 mmolMeOH·gcat -1·h-1 under optimal conditions. Extensive characterization results indicate that this exceptional activity originates from the synergistic optimization of both structure and reaction mechanism, driven by the interface confinement effect (ICE) enabled by abundant interfacial sites. Specifically, the surface of CZZ shows high density of highly dispersed Cu0 nanoparticles and rich oxygen vacancy sites, which is beneficial to the activation of H2 and the adsorption of CO2. In-situ DRIFTS further revealed that, compared to reference catalysts, CO2 hydrogenation on CZZ follows both the HCOO* and COOH* pathways, leading to a substantial improvement in overall catalytic activity. In summary, this study provides a deeper understanding of the ICE and their impacts on catalytic performance, offering a valuable theoretical insight for the design of high-performance catalysts in future research. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Methanol Cu-based catalysts Ternary interface Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction CO2 is one of the primary drivers of the global greenhouse effect. However, due to the intensification of human activities over the past few decades, its atmospheric concentration has risen rapidly. The challenge we now face extends beyond the impact of climate change to the detrimental effects of CO2 itself [1,2]. Nevertheless, CO2 can also serve as a valuable carbon resource for sustainable development. Among various utilization strategies, CO2 hydrogenation offers a promising route for converting CO2 into high value-added chemicals, such as methanol, synthesis gas and dimethyl ether. Among these products, methanol is particularly significant as a key chemical feedstock for producing formaldehyde, acetic acid, and other derivatives. Additionally, it serves as a clean fuel and solvent with widespread applications in energy, chemical, and pharmaceutical industries [3,4]. CO2 hydrogenation to methanol typically involves the use of non-noble metal catalysts (e.g., Cu-based, In-based, etc.) and noble metal catalysts (e.g., Pd-based, Pt-based, etc.), which are supported on various carriers such as SiO2, ZrO2, CeO2, and carbon-based materials like nanotubes (CNTs) [5–9]. Cu-based catalysts are widely utilized in CO2 hydrogenation due to their low cost, environmental friendliness, and ease of modification [10–14]. Currently, CuZnAl catalysts are extensively applied in the industrial production of methanol from syngas. However, their performance is constrained by low selectivity, instability, and susceptibility to sintering. To address these limitations, extensive research efforts have been devoted to incorporating additional components into Cu-based catalysts to enhance CO2 conversion efficiency and methanol selectivity [15]. Among these, the Cu/ZnO catalyst exhibits excellent catalytic performance, and further modifications to the Cu/ZnO system can lead to significant improvements. Al2O3 and ZrO2 are commonly employed as promoters and supports [5,16–18], as seen in the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 and Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 formulations. Notably, ZrO2 differs from Al2O3 in its lower hydrophilicity, which helps mitigate catalyst deactivation caused by water during the reaction [19]. Additionally, ZrO2 enhances the dispersion of Cu species and increases surface alkalinity, thereby promoting CO2 conversion and enhancing methanol selectivity [20]. Despite these advancements, the presence of complex interfaces poses a challenge to clearly understanding the influence of interfacial interactions on actual active sites and reaction mechanisms [21]. According to previous reports, the Cu-ZrO2 and Cu-ZnO interfacial contacts in CuZnZr catalysts are considered active centers for methanol synthesis, while various Cu species induced by secondary effects may also play critical roles in the process [22]. For example, Zhao et al. [23] identified that isolated Cuδ⁺ atoms confined within amorphous zirconia served as the true active centers for low-temperature methanol synthesis, whereas weaker interfacial interactions led to the formation of large Cu0 particles, which were ineffective in activating CO2. In Cu/ZnO interface-mediated catalysts, Cu, Cuδ+ [24], and CuZn alloys [25] formed during the reaction are all potential active centers for methanol production. These findings highlight the significant role of interfacial interactions in the formation and evolution of active sites. Regarding reaction mechanisms, the formate-mediated pathway (CO2 → HCOO* → H3CO* → CH3OH) [26,27], the RWGS + CO hydrogenation pathway (CO2 → CO* → CHO* → CH2O* → CH3O* → CH3OH) [28,29], and the COOH*-mediated pathway (CO2 → COOH* → H3CO* → CH3OH) [30,31] are the most commonly proposed. Similarly, variations in interfacial interactions may lead to distinct reaction pathways. For instance, in the Cu₁/ZnO system reported by Wu et al., the presence of water molecules directed the reaction along the COOH* → CH2O* → CH3OH pathway, with HCOO* acting as a spectator [30]. In contrast, Zhang et al. found that the hydrogenation of HCOO* dominated at the inverse ZnO1-x/Cu catalyst interface [32]. Meanwhile, Huang et al. proposed that CO* generated via RWGS on the Er–CuZnO surface served as the key reaction intermediate [33]. Notably, in catalysts with complex interfacial structures, multiple reaction mechanisms may coexist [34]. In summary, there is an urgent need for the rational design of active interfaces in catalysts to advance our understanding of active sites and reaction mechanisms. Here, a series of Cu-Zn-Zr catalysts with different contact interfaces by simply altering the loading sequence of metal precursors were precisely designed. Combined with the results of catalytic performance and ex/in-situ characterizations, the impact of interactions between different counterparts on modification of active sites and reaction pathways was investigated in detail. It was found that CuZnZr catalyst synthesized via the coprecipitation method, characterized by abundant Cu0 species and CO2 absorbed sites induced by the rich interface, exhibited optimized catalytic performance, achieving a CO2 conversion of 13.3 % and a space-time yield (STY) of 12.2 mmolMeOH·gcat −1·h−1. This work provides a deeper insight into understanding the metal-support interaction (MSI) and nature of the structure-activity relationship. 2 Catalyst synthesis and characterization 2.1 Preparation of catalysts 2.1.1 Synthesis of Cu/Zn-Zr-CP CZZ catalysts were prepared by the coprecipitation method with Na2CO3 (Aladdin, AR, ≥99.5 %) as precipitant. Firstly, 1.215 g Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (Aladdin, ≥99 %), 2.924 g Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (Aladdin, AR, ≥99 %) and 2.787 g Zr(NO3)4 5H2O (Aladdin, AR, ≥99.5 %) were weighed according to the metal load, and they were dissolved together in 100 mL deionized water, which was recorded as solution A. Then weigh an appropriate amount of 2.715 g Na2CO3 and dissolve it in 100 mL deionized water and record it as solution B. Slowly drip the solutions A and B into another beaker with 100 mL deionized water at a speed of 0.3 mL·min-1 with a peristaltic pump. During the dripping process, keep the stirring speed of 350 rpm·min-1 and heat it at 80 °C until the dripping is completed. Then aging at 80 °C for 2 h, cooling to room temperature after aging, washing with deionized water until pH = 7, and oven drying at 80 °C overnight. Finally, it was ground into powder and calcined for 5 h at 2 °C·min-1 to 350 °C in muffle furnace. For simplification, the catalyst was labeled as CZZ. 2.1.2 Synthesis of Cu/Zn-Zr-IWI Firstly, 2.787 g Zr(NO3)4·5H2O (Aladdin, AR, ≥99.5 %) and 2.924 g Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (Aladdin, ≥99 %) are weighed according to the metal load, and they are dissolved together in 100 mL deionized water, and recorded as solution A. Then weigh an appropriate amount of 2.076 g Na2CO3 (Aladdin, AR, ≥99.5 %) and dissolve it in 100 mL deionized water, and record it as solution B. Slowly drip the solutions A and B into another beaker with 100 mL deionized water at a speed of 0.3 mL·min-1 with a peristaltic pump. During the dripping process, keep the stirring speed of 350 rpm·min-1 and heat it at 80 °C until the dripping is completed. Then aging at 80 °C for 2 h, cooling to room temperature after aging, washing with deionized water until pH = 7, and oven drying at 80 °C overnight. Finally, it was ground into powder and calcined for 5 h at 2 °C·min-1 to 350 °C in muffle furnace. The powder was prepared by an equal-volume impregnation method. 1.332 g Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (Aladdin, ≥99 %) was dissolved in a proper amount of water, added dropwise, and continuously stirred and ground with a glass rod, then aged at room temperature for 2 h, and dried in an oven at 80 °C overnight. Finally, grinding into powder, calcining for 5 h at 2 °C·min-1 to 350 °C in a muffle furnace to synthesize Cu-ZZ. For simplify, the catalyst was labeled as Cu-ZZ. 2.1.3 Synthesis of Zn/Cu-Zr-IWI and synthesis of Zr/Cu-Zn-IWI The synthesis process is the same as in Section 2.1.2, with only the loading sequence changed. The catalysts were labeled Zn-CZ and Zr-CZ, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization XRD. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were measured on a Rigaku Smartlab diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation and a nickel filter in the 2θ angle range from 5 to 90° (10°·min-1) at 40 kV and 40 mA. BET. Nitrogen physisorption was carried out on an ASAP 2020 (Micrometrics) instrument at 77 K (-196 °C) after outgassing the samples for 6 h under a vacuum at 300 °C. TEM. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were recorded by a FEI Talos F200S G2 at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. H2-TPR/CO2-TPD. The temperature-programmed experiments were tested on an Autochem II 2920 instrument (Micrometrics) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). In a typical H2-TPR experiment, the samples were pretreated in a helium stream at 300 °C for 120 min to remove moisture on the surface. 10 % H2/He was passed into the reactor, with the temperature increasing at 10 °C·min−1 to 700 °C, and data were recorded every 0.5 min. The CO2-TPD profile was also recorded on the AutoChem II 2920 instrument (Micrometrics). The samples were pretreated in a helium stream at 300 °C for 120 min to remove moisture on the surface. Then cooled down to room temperature and saturated by 10 % CO2/Ar for 30 min. After purging the physically adsorbed hydrogen on the surface with helium. The temperature slowly increased to 700 °C and the detector recorded a signal at the same time. In situ DRIFTS. In-situ infrared analysis was carried out on the instrument of NiCOlet iS50 FTIR, and the CO adsorption behavior of the catalyst could be determined by CO-DRIFTS characterization. The sample was pretreated at 300 °C for 2 h in 10 ml·min-1 H2 atmosphere. After the pretreatment, switch to 10 ml·min-1 Ar purging for 30 min to remove excess H2 and cool down to room temperature to scan the background spectrum (scanning times 32, resolution 4 cm-1). Introduce 10 ml·min-1 CO gas into the in-situ cell for adsorption and record the CO adsorption spectrum until the spectrum is basically the same. Finally, the gaseous CO peak was swept away by Ar blowing and the spectrum was scanned with time. In-situ infrared experiment can analyze the intermediate species in the reaction process. The adsorption gas CO is changed into the reaction gas with CO2/H2/Ar ratio of 24:72:4, and the flow rate is set to 10 ml·min-1. At 200 °C and 3.0 MPa, the spectrogram is collected and analyzed, and the spectrogram is stopped when there is no obvious change. XPS. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) can analyze the elemental composition and chemical state of samples. The XPS characterization involved in this experiment was measured by the model ESCALAB 250 energy spectrum analyzer produced by Thermo-Fisher Company. All samples were sealed and sent for testing after pretreatment and reaction atmosphere treatment. In the experiment, A1 target is used as X-ray source (monochromatic 150 W, Al Kα, 1486.6 eV), with working voltage of 12 kV and working current of 20 mA. All binding energies are charged corrected by C1s (284.8 eV). 2.3 Catalytic testing All the catalytic reactions were carried out in a high-pressure fixed-bed microreactor. Typically, 200 mg of each catalyst (40∼60 meshes) was mixed with 1.3 g of quartz sand (30∼40 meshes) were pretreated in H2 at 200 °C in the flow of 40 mL·min-1 for 2 h. Then the reactant gases (CO2/H2/Ar=24/72/4, 3.0 MPa, 250 °C) were introduced into the reactor. The product gas was analyzed with an online gas chromatograph (GC, SHIMADZU) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a thermal conductivity detector. The performance of catalysts was evaluated by CO2 conversion, product selectivity, ethanol yield and space-time yield (STY). W(g) is the weight of catalyst. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Catalytic properties The effects of different Cu-Zn-Zr interfaces on activity were investigated by varying the metal precursor sequence using coprecipitation and impregnation methods. First, the influence of different weight hourly space velocities (WHSV) on reaction activity at 250 °C was examined (Fig. 1a -b). As WHSV increased, CO2 conversion, product distribution, and methanol space-time yield (STY) of the main catalyst exhibited an upward trend. Due to the limitations of the maximum flow rate in the fixed-bed reactor, the catalyst amount was reduced to enhance space velocity. Therefore, the reaction conditions of 250 °C, 3.0 MPa, a catalyst dosage of 0.2 g, and WHSV of 12000 ml·gcat -1·h-1 were selected to evaluate the activity of the comparative catalyst. A comparison of the activities of the four catalysts groups revealed significant differences depending on the metal loading sequence (Fig. 1c-d, and Table S1). Specifically, as shown in Fig. 1c, the CZZ catalyst exhibited the highest CO₂ conversion (13.3 %), while the CO2 conversion of Cu-ZZ, Zn-CZ, and Zr-CZ were notably lower. In contrast, methanol selectivity showed only slight variations among the four catalysts. The Zr-CZ catalyst exhibited the highest methanol selectivity (81.2 %), whereas the CZZ catalyst, despite its superior CO2 conversion, had a slightly lower methanol selectivity (71.3 %) compared to the other samples. Regarding the space-time yield (STY) of methanol, since the selectivity differences among the four samples were relatively minor, the STY trend was primarily influenced by CO2 conversion. As a result, the CZZ catalyst exhibited the highest STY of 12.2 mmolMeOH·gcat -1·h-1 (Fig. 1d). This outcome was likely attributed to differences in the interfaces between Cu, Zn, and Zr, which affect CO2 activation and subsequently influence catalytic performance. Moreover, compared to the performance of catalysts reported in literature for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, the CZZ catalyst exhibits higher methanol STY and lower reaction temperature per gram of catalyst in Fig. S1. In addition, long-term stability assessments further confirmed the superiority of the CZZ catalyst (Fig. 1e). Under continuous reaction for 100 h at standard reaction conditions, both CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity maintained stable performance without detectable deactivation. This result highlights the excellent stability of the Cu-Zn-Zr catalyst prepared by the coprecipitation method. 3.2 Structural and chemical properties Four fresh Cu-Zn-Zr catalysts with different metal loading sequences were characterized by XRD. As shown in Fig. S2, all four samples showed two distinct crystalline phases, along with amorphous ZrO2. The characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ = 31.7°, 34.4°, 36.2° and 47.5° corresponded to the (100), (002), (101) and (102) crystal planes of ZnO, while the peaks at 2θ = 35.6°, 38.8°, 48.7°, 58.4° and 68.2° were attributed to CuO [35]. Notably, the peak intensities of these two species were prominent in the Cu-ZZ, Zn-CZ, and Zr-CZ samples but were significantly weaker or even undetectable in the CZZ sample. Therefore, we believed that CuO and ZnO in the CZZ sample had smaller particle sizes, which could be attributed to the unique interfacial confinement effect within the catalyst. The used samples were also tested by XRD and the results were displayed in Fig. 2a . The diffraction peaks of ZrO2 and ZnO remained unchanged, whereas CuO was mostly reduced to metallic Cu0. Notably, Cu0 species in CZZ exhibited the smallest particle size, which might be attributed to the confinement effects provided by the abundant interfacial contacts. The particle sizes of different species were further calculated using the Scherrer equation, with the results presented in Table S2. Compared to the other three samples, CZZ exhibited the smallest ZnO, CuO, and Cu0 particle sizes, consistent with the XRD findings. Given that CZZ demonstrated the highest catalytic activity, it was reasonable to conclude that the coprecipitation-synthesized CZZ possessed the richest interfacial contacts (e.g., Cu0||ZnO, Cu0||ZrO2), which not only enhanced the dispersion of Cu0 nanoparticle but also significantly improved CO2 activation. H2-TPR was employed to examine the reduction behavior of different catalysts. The shape, location and area of the reduction peak are primarily associated with the properties, dispersity and quantity of active component Cu [36]. Generally, metal oxides other than CuO in the catalyst were not reduced to below 300 °C [37,38]. As depicted in Fig. 2b, all four catalysts exhibited reduction peaks within the temperature range of 100∼300 °C. The CZZ displayed three distinct reduction peaks, whereas the other three catalysts exhibited two, denoted as α, β and γ. The former two reduction peaks correspond to the stepwise reduction processes of Cu2+→Cu+ and Cu+→Cu0 [39,40]. Considering the synthesis method of CZZ, we reasonably attributed the γ signal to the reduction of Cu oxides dissolved in the ZnZrOx solid-solution bulk. Meanwhile, the reduction peaks in CZZ appeared at low temperature (<250 °C), whereas those in Cu-ZZ, Zn-CZ, and Zr-CZ shifted to higher temperatures. This suggests that the abundant interface in CZZ facilitated the formation of various Cu components and enhanced Cu0 dispersion, which was consistent with the XRD results. CO2-TPD characterization was performed to analyze the surface basicity of the catalysts. Three desorption peaks, labeled as α, β, and γ, were observed in the temperature range of 100–700 °C. The α peak at 160 °C corresponds to weakly basic sites associated with surface -OH groups [41]. The two high-temperature peaks above 400 °C (β and γ) correspond to the moderately basic sites related to metal-oxygen electron pairs and strongly basic sites attributed to low-coordination O2- species [42]. As shown in Fig. 2c, the primary catalyst of CZZ exhibited a higher concentration of weakly basic sites. According to previous literature [43,44], weak and moderately basic sites in the low-temperature region facilitate CO2 activation and its conversion into intermediate species. In contrast, excessive strong basic sites can hinder the desorption of HCOO* intermediates, thereby impeding the subsequent hydrogenation of HCOO* to CH3O*. Therefore, the abundance of weak and moderately basic sites in the CZZ catalyst promoted CO2 activation, ultimately leading to the highest CO2 conversion rate among the studied catalysts. TEM images and EDS mapping of reduced catalysts were presented in Fig. 3 , providing further insights into microstructure of the prepared samples. As shown in the EDS mapping of CZZ (Fig. 3a), Cu and Zn particles were uniformly dispersed. However, varying degrees of Cu agglomeration were observed on the surfaces of the other three catalysts (Fig. 3b-d). High-resolution TEM images reveal diffraction fringes in all four catalysts. ZrO2 species exhibited amorphous state due to no related lattices being detected in all samples. As shown in Fig. 3a, the measured lattice spacing of 2.4 Å corresponded to ZnO (101), while no lattice fringes of Cu species were observed [45]. Furthermore, an abundant intimate interface between amorphous ZrO2 and ZnO was detected, highlighted by the yellow/red dash line. In the other three samples, in addition to the lattice fringes corresponding to ZnO, most importantly, lattice fringes of Cu0 particles were clearly visible-except for Zn-CZ, possibly due to overlap with ZnO. Therefore, the co-precipitated catalyst not only provided sufficient interfacial contact but also promoted the high dispersion of Cu0 particles, which was consistent with the XRD observations. The textural properties of different catalysts were investigated by BET (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller) test. As shown in Fig. S3, the nitrogen adsorption and desorption curves of CZZ, Cu-ZZ, Zn-CZ and Zr-CZ exhibited type IV isotherms. When the relative pressure was in the range of 0.4∼1.0, CZZ showed a distinct type Ⅲ hysteresis loop, indicating the presence of both micropores and mesopores, whereas Cu-ZZ, Zn-CZ and Zr-CZ displayed type Ⅳ hysteresis loop, primarily associated with micropores [46,47]. Table S3 further revealed that the specific surface area and pore size of CZZ were obviously larger than those of the other three catalysts, demonstrating the highest adsorption capacity. A larger the pore size correlates with an increased specific surface area and pore volume, facilitating the dispersion of active Cu0 particles. In contrast, Cu-ZZ, Zn-CZ and Zr-CZ showed reduced specific surface area and pore size, likely due to pore blockage by Cu0 nanoparticles during impregnation [48]. These findings confirmed that Cu species in CZZ with highest dispersion, and its largest specific surface could provide abundant adsorption sites for reactants. 3.3 Chemical valence state and reaction mechanism at the interface The surface species and valence states of CZZ-U, Cu-ZZ-U, Zn-CZ-U and Zr-CZ-U catalysts were characterized by XPS. The chemical states of Cu species after the reaction were shown in Fig. 4 . As seen in the XPS spectrum (Fig. 4a), the binding energy peaks at 930∼938 eV and 950∼958 eV correspond to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 orbitals, respectively [49]. The presence of satellite peaks at 940∼947 eV and 960∼965 eV confirmed the existence of Cu2+ [50]. After literature comparison, the peak at 932.7 eV was attributed to Cu0/Cu+, indicating that Cu species exist in a reduced state [51]. Notably, the Cu 2p3/2 peak in Zn-CZ-U (933.0 eV, 934.5 eV) shifted to higher binding energy compared to CZZ-U, Cu-ZZ-U and Zr-CZ-U, which suggested that there was a decrease in local electron density around Cu species. This shift aligned with the H₂-TPR results, indicating the more challenging reduction of CuO. Fig. 4b showed that the peaks at 1021.7 eV and 1044.9 eV belong to Zn2+ in ZnO [52,53]. Compared to Cu-ZZ-U, the binding energy of Zn 2p3/2 in CZZ-U, Zn-CZ-U and Zr-CZ-U shifted to low value, indicating the presence of reduced ZnOx species. Similarly, the peaks at 182.1 eV and 184.5 eV in Fig. S4 attributed to Zr 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2 , respectively [54]. In addition, O 1s XPS spectra of the various catalysts were shown in Fig. S5 and were deconvoluted into three components: lattice oxygen (OL), oxygen vacancies (OV), and hydroxyl oxygen (OOH) [55]. The relative concentration of these O species were further quantified, as summarized in Table S4. Among the catalysts, CZZ and Zn-CZ exhibited higher OV contents, reaching 65.1 % and 65.2 %, respectively. In contrast, Cu-ZZ and Zr-CZ showed lower surface OV concentrations, with only 48.7 % and 45.7 %. These results suggested that CZZ and Zn-CZ possessed more CO2 adsorption sites, which correlated well with their higher CO2 conversion rates. The Cu+/Cu0 species in each catalyst were further analyzed by auger electron spectroscopy (AES). The peaks observed at 916.8 eV, 917.7 eV, and 918.6 eV were reasonably assigned to Cu+, Cu2+ and Cu0, respectively (Fig. 4c) [56]. It is observed that CZZ-U exhibited the highest Cu0 content (32.2 %), while the lowest in the case of Zn-CZ (11.6 %). According to previous studies by Arena [57] and Dasireddy [58], Cu0 was the responsible species compared to Cu+ while generation of methanol from CO2 hydrogenation, and our findings aligned with these results. Although CZZ and Zn-CZ showed nearly equal OV content, the limited amount of Cu0 sites on the surface of Zn-CZ weakened the ability to dissociate H2, which was not conducive to the hydrogenation of CO2 on active sites [59]. Hence, we believed that the abundant OV on the CZZ catalyst surface facilitated CO2 adsorption. In addition, the small Cu0 nanoparticles provided a high metallic surface area with a greater number of unsaturated atoms, which facilitated H2 dissociation and lowered the activation barrier for CO2 activation, thereby enhancing the overall catalytic performance [60]. DRIFT-CO was conducted to investigate the absorption behavior of CO on the surface of catalysts. As shown in Fig. S6, two broad and intense absorption bands were observed at about 2172 cm–1 and 2117 cm–1, corresponding to the linear adsorption of CO on Cu [61]. Within ten minutes of CO introduction, the absorption bands of all four catalysts reached saturation. Upon Ar purging, both bands gradually weakened and completely disappeared within ten minutes, indicating that the catalysts exhibited weak adsorption capacity and that stable chemisorption was unlikely. The catalysts were further characterized by in-situ DRIFTS under reaction conditions (CO2:H2=1:3, 3.0 MPa, 200 °C), as shown in Fig. 5 . The vibrational peak assignments were summarized in Table S5. For the CZZ catalyst, the peak at 1696 cm-1 corresponded to ionic bicarbonate species (i-HCO3*), while the peak at 1225 cm-1 was attributed to bidentate bicarbonate species (b-HCO3*) [62]. Additionally, peaks at 1599 cm-1, 1387 cm-1, and 1362 cm-1 were associated with νas (OCO), δ (CH) and νs (OCO), respectively, which corresponded to the HCOO* intermediates. Two absorption peaks were detected at 1140 cm-1 and 2835 cm-1 correspond to methoxy (CH3O*) species, specifically bridge ν (CO) and νs (CH3) [63]. Notably, in addition to the active intermediate HCOO*, two distinct spectral peaks at 1287 cm-1 and 1750 cm-1, corresponding to carboxylate COOH* species, were detected with significantly higher intensity on the surface of CZZ. This observation suggested that CO2 hydrogenation to methanol on the CZZ catalyst followed a synergistic mechanism involving both HCOO* and COOH* [64]. This dual-pathway mechanism may be the key factor contributing to the superior catalytic activity of the CZZ catalyst. In contrast, on the surfaces of Cu-ZZ, Zn-CZ, and Zr-CZ catalysts, nearly only the HCOO* intermediate was detected, indicating that these catalysts follow a single HCOO* hydrogenation pathway. 4 Conclusion The co-precipitated CZZ catalyst contains abundant active interfaces (Cu||ZnO, Cu||ZrO2), which exhibit a superior synergistic promotion effect. Structurally, the interfacial confinement effect (ICE) not only increases the proportion of surface Cu0 but also enhances the dispersion of Cu0 nanoparticles, providing sufficient active sites for CO2 and H2 activation. In terms of the reaction pathway, the abundant active interfaces induce CO2 hydrogenation to proceed via both the HCOO* and COOH* pathways, significantly improving the hydrogenation efficiency of the surface intermediates. Consequently, in terms of catalytic activity, CZZ demonstrates excellent methanol synthesis performance. Under optimized reaction conditions (250 °C, 3.0 MPa, CO2:H2=1:3, WHSV=12000 mL·gcat -1· h-1), it achieves a CO2 conversion of 13.3 %, a methanol selectivity of 71.3 %, and a space-time yield (STY) of 12.2 mmol MeOH·gcat ⁻¹·h⁻¹, significantly outperforming reference catalysts with insufficient active interfaces. This work not only provides a clear understanding of the nature of interfacial confinement effects and their influence on active sites and reaction mechanisms but also offers theoretical guidance for the design of high-performance catalysts in the future. coredata.dc:description: Tuning metal-support interactions in catalysts represents a promising strategy for optimizing the catalytic activity of CO2 hydrogenation. Here, CuZnZr ternary catalysts with varied interfacial structures were fabricated by altering the metal loading sequence to elucidate the interactions between different counterparts. Compared to reference catalysts with different interfaces (Cu-ZnZr, Zn-CuZr and Zr-CuZn), CuZnZr synthesized via the coprecipitation method (CZZ) displays the highest catalytic performance, achieving a CO2 conversion rate of 13.3 %, methanol selectivity of 71.3 %, and a STY of 12.2 mmolMeOH·gcat -1·h-1 under optimal conditions. Extensive characterization results indicate that this exceptional activity originates from the synergistic optimization of both structure and reaction mechanism, driven by the interface confinement effect (ICE) enabled by abundant interfacial sites. Specifically, the surface of CZZ shows high density of highly dispersed Cu0 nanoparticles and rich oxygen vacancy sites, which is beneficial to the activation of H2 and the adsorption of CO2. In-situ DRIFTS further revealed that, compared to reference catalysts, CO2 hydrogenation on CZZ follows both the HCOO* and COOH* pathways, leading to a substantial improvement in overall catalytic activity. In summary, this study provides a deeper understanding of the ICE and their impacts on catalytic performance, offering a valuable theoretical insight for the design of high-performance catalysts in future research.

coredata.dc:title: Boosting CO2 hydrogenation to methanol via ternary Cu-Zn-Zr catalyst: The critical role of interface confinement effect (ICE)
